data.title: In conversation with the spin doctor: Luca Morisi
data.meta_description: Interview with Luca Morisi, communication director of Matteo Salvini. Find out more on his team and the so-called "Beast". And more: Russia, Trump, the "bots", the hate speechâ€¦

â€œDonâ€™t call me a spin doctor: Salviniâ€™s spin doctor is Salvini himselfâ€. Luca Morisi, head of Matteo Salviniâ€˜s communication team, joined the 2018 edition of Election Days as a speaker. Morisi had already been guest at ED last year and two years ago. But this time around, his speech was highly anticipated: the Leagueâ€™s recent electoral score and â€“ even more â€“ the great role played by Matteo Salvini once the new government was formed, raised a lot of interest (even outside of Italy) about the â€œtricksâ€ of his communication. Morisi also talked about the so-called â€œBeastâ€, a software his team has been using over the past few years to optimize tasks and activities, as Morisi demonstrated to the participants of ED. No â€œevil algorithmâ€: â€œThe Beast is a cooperative software for the automation of activities â€“ such as cross-posting, graph creation, event promotion, news monitoringâ€. Morisi also undermines his own role and that of its staff. â€œSalviniâ€™s strength is that he is in charge of his communication. He is a champion of disintermediation and an absolute perfectionist. We help him, of course, but thereâ€™s only one spin doctor in Salviniâ€™s team, and itâ€™s Salvini himselfâ€.

You already told us something about â€œthe Beastâ€, but you said you also use web listening tools: what do they reveal to you, in order to whatâ€™s best to publish?

â€œIt is offensive to suggest that there are such automations behind what we post. It offends Salvini and our ability to do our jobâ€

These tools donâ€™t do things like sentiment analysis or issue-based aggregation of comments: those are things we do â€œmanuallyâ€, thereâ€™s no automatic listening. After years of living on the social networks, we and Salvini â€“ heâ€™s got a real â€œsenseâ€ for communication â€“ know how to read the trends. When you spend your days reading, comparing, watching what people think, which are the issues of our best performing posts, you â€œmanuallyâ€ understand whatâ€™s good to talk about. Therefore, no algorithm or automation needed: everything relies on Salviniâ€™s â€œsenseâ€ and on our subsequent analysis on the performance of what we publish.

Can you tell us about a concrete instance? How do you understand whatâ€™s best to talk about?

I can tell you a recent one: some days ago Salvini talked about self-defense. We saw huge attention on this issue. But we didnâ€™t see it from the â€œBeastâ€: we saw it from the fact that our live tweeting of a TV show focused on this issue reached a huge engagement. Thatâ€™s how you understand if itâ€™s something you should talk about. And thatâ€™s why a FB post by Salvini the following day was all about this, and reached almost 100k likes. But thereâ€™s no algorithm, no automation: thereâ€™s a lot of knowledge, a lot of attention and tenacity in our exploration of what people say on the web. â€œThe Beastâ€ doesnâ€™t do any qualitative monitoring of comments and/or interactions. Iâ€™ll tell you more: it is offensive to suggest that there are such automations behind what we post. It offends Salvini, and our ability to do our job.

Some people have expressed critical skepticism about the way the data of the FB users that joined the â€œVinci Salviniâ€ [â€œWin Salviniâ€] game were managed. Whatâ€™s your answer to this?

The users who signed in the â€œVinci Salviniâ€ game were totally aware of the fact they were giving their basic data. A registration on a FB app was required â€“ we used 100% legal and official FB tools only, there was no homemade tool â€“ and this app simply registered the flow of likes and comments, and associated their ID with the usersâ€™. But that was only meant to establish the name of the game winner each day, and to send emails only to those users who had chosen to give us their address beforehand. The data were not used for any kind of profiling.

Some people though linked this case to the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Both these stories are about the use of the FB userâ€™s data for a political aim. Isnâ€™t that true?

Thereâ€™s nothing in common with the Cambridge Analytica story here. That case was about selling data gathered with a pseudo-scientific psychological test, for electoral aims. We did nothing even close to that. But we should always keep in mind that in the digital era, unfortunately, everything we do is tracked: if something is free â€“ including social networks â€“ it means the user himself is the product. There are always distortions and abuses, but itâ€™s ridiculous to get upset about your privacy when you offer your personal life to the public on the SN in the first place.

Steve Bannon stated (to Reuters) that your communication along with that of the Five Star has been very innovative. But now youâ€™re telling us that you invented nothing, except for the â€œVinci Salviniâ€ game. Who is right?

As I told to the participants at Election Days, there has been innovation: many techniques of posting, graphic composition of cards and banners, mailing list management, filling videos with info, manufacturing contentâ€¦ We invented a lot of stuff, in my opinion. I might be little immodest by saying it, but in many cases we have been the first in Italy. The â€œVinci Salviniâ€ game was the most important, from a merely technological point of view. But we have more in mind, things that I wonâ€™t reveal even if you torture meâ€¦

The FB live video is almost the main form of communication for Salvini and Di Maio as well. I understand why a politician or a political consultant may prefer it, as thereâ€™s no journalists to deal with. But if you step out of your role for a moment, can you tell me if you agree that this can potentially become a problem for the dÃ©bat public?

â€œThe news media arenâ€™t going to die because of Salviniâ€™s FB lives. But they have to change to adapt to the digital revolutionâ€

It is a problem because it tends to create the so-called â€œeco chambersâ€. In particular on Facebook, where people mostly see and share contents they already agree with. This doesnâ€™t help cross-contamination, which I believe to be a richness. But thereâ€™s a mirroring game with traditional media: the leader speaks in real time but then his words are commented in the public discussion, such as in talk shows. So the disintermediation of FB live doesnâ€™t damage the public discussion, even though it ends up reducing the work for press officers and journalistsâ€¦

So you advised Salvini to use this tool?

He needed no advice on this, it came spontaneously because heâ€™s got a strong empathy, as everybody who meets him â€“ even for a few seconds â€“ can see. Itâ€™s an ideal tool for him that he embraced immediately. Itâ€™s a good way to jump over the mediation of newspapers and press offices. The news media then use those videos to provide information, they arenâ€™t going to die because of this. They have to change to adapt of course: the digital revolution requires evolution by the information players.

Hereâ€™s some questions coming live from Twitter. Have you ever had, as Salvini and the Leagueâ€™s communication staff, contacts with the Russia?

Never, never, never. Hereâ€™s a funny story: there was a period when Bobo Craxi [son of Bettino Craxi, former italian PM back in the 80s] replied to anyone contesting him on Twitter with things like â€œMorisi is that you?â€, â€œMorisi itâ€™s you, I get itâ€, â€œMorisi you were in Russia, did they teach you the techniques?â€â€¦ Well, of course not. Everything we built was not from Trump or from Putin. We did a lot of things before Trump did. Salvini started this very intensive, unfiltered use of the social networks back in 2012, Trump came well after then. I went to Russia a couple of times, but I know no one from Putinâ€™s party and I have nobody there who gives me support.

During your speech at ED you said â€œthe people are on Facebookâ€. Then why all this focus on Twitter?

In Italy there are 30 million people on Facebook. Compared to that, Twitter is half-empty. Even the actual number of active users is unknown: there might be 6, 7 million, maybe 8. If you use it frequently, you will realize that itâ€™s always the same people talking about politics. Moreover, they have nicknames, and insult users who show their real face and name. Sometimes people tell us that our public is made of scum: fascist, racist peopleâ€¦ But on the other side of the political spectrum people are no different. If you look at the tweets people write me, itâ€™s an endless series of insults. Our success on Twitter is due to the fact that a small universe like that is easy to climb: if you have a small group of devoted people, retweeting a certain hashtag, if your communication is intense, you can climb the italian trends very quickly.

Some people say that you make use of botsâ€¦

â€œI have never â€“ never â€“ created or managed fake profiles on Twitter or Facebook to increase engagement artificially. There are real people that subscribe only because they love Salvini and want to support himâ€

Absolutely not. Back in 2014 we created a sort of game, â€œBe Salviniâ€™s spokesmanâ€, which was talked about a lot, even on TV. Registered users accepted to automatically tweet some of the contents tweeted by Salvini. Not fake people, but real ones who accepted to sign a â€œblind permissionâ€ to tweet certain contents on certain occasions. We used it, but marginally. And it helped, but marginally. Twitterâ€™s algorithm is not merely based on quantity, you must have also a plurality of different sources, and thatâ€™s why we used this tool along with channels (such as Telegram messages). What really matters is to publish many things together in a short time.

Are you still using this tool?

No, we donâ€™t use it anymore. Since January, or February, I believe. It no longer exists.

So the campaigns of the past months are â€˜organicâ€™?

Absolutely. Iâ€™m thinking of suing some people because of the things I happen to read. I have never â€“ never â€“ created or managed fake profiles on Twitter or Facebook to increase engagement artificially , the number of retweets or the popularity of the hashtags. We have never used these tactics. The only one we used, which I mentioned few minutes ago, was based on a voluntary acceptance from the users (I think no more than 200 people). And we used that rarely and we donâ€™t even use it anymore. Plus, it was no secret , as it was easily visible through the Twitter logs. But today thereâ€™s such a strong group, even on Twitter, that we wouldnâ€™t even need it again. Today we have people subscribing on Twitter only to support Salvini, partially thanks to our subscription campaigns. There are real people that subscribe only because they love Salvini and want to support him.

Whatâ€™s your position about hate speech to minorities, or immigrants? I quote a tweet from Sofia Ventura who asks you to explain â€œhow to push the hate of minorities in order to make it an instrument of powerâ€. Many people care about this issue. Do you think thereâ€™s a risk of lighting a fire?

We basically describe reality. If you go outside through the neighborhood you will realize how many worrying elements there are. In the era of social networks, thousands of people were offered the opportunity to become â€œauthorsâ€. Before that, people talked about these things at home, with their friends, at the bar. Now the informal â€“ sometimes uninformed, excessive â€“ chats have risen to a public dimension. Sofia Ventura looks at immigration and does so from a left-wing perspective, but this is also about the things people say about Salvini, who is suffering a real hate campaign: people who call him â€œmurdererâ€, who want to â€œhangâ€ him, Asia Argento tweeting â€œSalvini s**tâ€. This is the information universe we have to operate in. Politicians must play a role in curbing unacceptable behaviours. But itâ€™s a matter of fact that people today feel legitimated to say unacceptable things. Before social networks, only a small fraction of people was able to comment the news in public: today, it takes just a minute to open an account and say the most stupid things.

Ok, we agree on the fact that thereâ€™s hate everywhere, even outside social networks. But donâ€™t you think that Salvini, with his communication style, makes things worse?

â€œEvery time the technological paradigm changes and this has an impact on information, the paradigm changes on many other levels as well. This is the paradigm we have to deal with today, and each of us has to deal with the existing audienceâ€

Salvini offers a picture of reality, he does it with strong tones and people also like it for the realism and the clarity of the messages. He uses the tools that are available today. This is valid for the immigrant issue and others issues as well. They say we target minorities: but Iâ€™ve never seen or heard Salvini saying something against homosexuality. Heâ€™s kind of liberal on this, heâ€™s against gay adoptions, but heâ€™s got nothing against homosexuals. There are a lot of regular immigrants that love Salvini because of the uncontrolled invasion of irregular immigrants in the last years has put those who have been here from many years â€“ who are fully integrated and send their children to our schools â€“ on the same level as those that commit crime. These episodes show how this situation hurts the humblest people, mostly in the areas where the left used to be strongest. Social networks can be used in this way on many issues: immigration but also Brexit, or â€œTemptation Islandâ€â€¦ Not to mention all the cases of body shaming. We can like or not, but this is the situation on the web.

Donâ€™t you think that the switch from an â€œanalogâ€ to a â€œdigitalâ€ paradigm in public communication needs to be handled with care?

Thereâ€™s a dialogue by Plato â€“ I believe it was the Phaedrus â€“ where the switch from the oral era to the written document era is stigmatised, because â€“ they say in this dialogue â€“ when you remove words from the mouth and put them on a â€œdeadâ€ document, where the author is no longer present (with his gestures, the sound of his voice, etc) you turn those words into something â€œdangerousâ€ as they are separated from the speakerâ€™s will. Therefore, every time the technological paradigm changes and this has an impact on information, the paradigm changes on many other levels as well: the interaction between myself and others, gnoseology, ontology, ethics. This is the paradigm we have to deal with today, and each of us has to deal with the existing audience.

I have to move an objection. Today you are not only the political consultant and the social strategist of the League, you are a consultant to the Ministry of the Interior and the vice Prime Minister. Donâ€™t you think that this brings more responsibility to you and your team than before? Is it acceptable for the Minister of the Interior to speak in public wearing a Police shirt? To spread and comment on news stories in a certain way might be acceptable for a political leader, but what about a Minister of the Interior?

As I said before, Salvini is the only author of his communication. The way he decides to communicate in his new role of Minister of the Interior and vice PM is totally his choice. Iâ€™m not saying this to dissociate myself, to be clear. He is doing exactly what he did before, itâ€™s his way of communicating. Some people like it, others donâ€™t. I donâ€™t believe there are rules on how one interprets a role â€“ and by the way rules are not written in stone, they can be changed. Salvini became Minister of the Interior thanks to his political strength and the peopleâ€™s support. Many, even inside the League, used to see Salvini as a parvenu: when he became the partyâ€™s leader some said â€œYeah letâ€™s put him there, heâ€™s good at communicating, the serious job will be on usâ€. And then he showed his ability in the long period, not only with here-and-now communication.

Once you are in office in the Government you canâ€™t live of mere communication, do you agree?

â€œToday thereâ€™s people that question universal suffrage, instead of accepting a confrontation on different opinions. But this is how the very foundations of democracy are underminedâ€

I â€˜ve seen him in office, and I saw great organization skills. When he arrived at the Viminale he immediately took everything into his own hands, called all the employees, the heads of department. In a week he got used to the Viminale, said to be a very complicated machine. And thatâ€™s how you see that his success is not due to a â€œcommunication bubbleâ€, but because he does things. The League grew from 17% of last election to 32-33% in the most recent polls thanks to the fact that Salvini has done real things, perceived by the public opinion. The blocking of the ships, the security billâ€¦ One can have a left-wing vision, but is it fair that italian law allows a refugee to commit crime without losing his refugee rights? On self-defense: many people have been condemned to compensate thieves that entered their house. Is this right or wrong? Itâ€™s a matter of opinion. Yet, today thereâ€™s people that question universal suffrage, instead of accepting a confrontation on different opinions. But this is how the very foundations of democracy are undermined.

Can you explain more in detail how the FB group â€œSalvini leaderâ€ works?

The FB group was chosen because it allows a different kind of management from the FB page. In the group, the position of the posts depends on their engagement level, rather than on chronology. This group is moderated with very tight filters, but allows us to create an incredibly strong community spirit, different from a page. When we announce an event or initiative, through the group we can mobilize up to 65 thousands people, with very high engagement levels. If we ask the group to go and write on a certain page or to change their profile pic, these people just do it. And itâ€™s something self-feeding, and needs no bot or automation. These are real people, they didnâ€™t just appear: they form a fan club that we have been feeding for years.

You said that Salvini just describes reality, but the contents posted by him about negative news related to immigrants are way more than those related to Italians. Did you ever consider that there might be some responsibility in feeding stereotypes?

â€œThe â€œhere-and-nowâ€ communication on social networks gives new strength to stereotypes: everything is over-simplified, and factions rise everywhereâ€

Here we are in the field of opinion. My role and activities are technical, and they are about how Salvini communicates. But I donâ€™t think that there is anything in his logic that questions ethics. Thereâ€™s already a group of mainstream media that just donâ€™t talk too much about certain kinds of news, perhaps because they fear feeding stereotypes. But if they donâ€™t talk about that, I do. Whether itâ€™s right or wrong from the point of view of ethics is off topic. In italian jails the percentage of non-Italians is much higher than it is in the whole community, and this is a matter of fact. Itâ€™s data, not fake news.

Ok but feeding a stereotype can strengthen the stereotype itself, hurting those who are victims of it, donâ€™t you think?

Yes but this is true for everything. Confirmation bias regards all fields. My political positions arenâ€™t particularly radical â€“ in fact, those who know me well also know that my positions are more liberal than those of the League. The â€œhere-and-nowâ€ communication we see on the social networks today, unfortunately, gives new strength to stereotypes: everything is over-simplified, and factions rise everywhere. Not only on immigration: vaccines, abortion, euthanasia, are all divisive issues where factions and stereotypes become stronger thanks to social network dynamics.

(Photos: Alberto Cabodi)

The interview with Luca Morisi is the first of a series from Lorenzo Pregliasco and Giovanni Diamanti to some of the main experts of political and electoral communication. In the next issue: Filippo Sensi
